title: House Democrats Increase Pressure on Attorney General Barr
summary: Judiciary committee chairman sets Monday deadline for Justice Department to comply with subpoena on Mueller report. WASHINGTON-The Democratic-controlled House and the Trump administration careened toward a constitutional showdown Friday over special counsel Robert Mueller's report on Russian interference in the 2016 election.

title: Search for Buyout Targets Leads Public Investors to Biotech
summary: Startups head to public markets despite being in the earliest phases of research. Public investors' search for the next hot biotechnology acquisition target is helping even early-stage drugmakers to go public.

title: Vice Media Raises $250 Million in Debt From Group of Investors Including George Soros
summary: Once-hot new media company had been looking to raise additional capital amid stalling growth. Vice Media said it has raised $250 million in debt from a group of investors including George Soros, a move intended to help the struggling new media company fund its turnaround strategy.

title: Ohio Gerrymander Struck Down as Supreme Court Weighs Issue
summary: Decision overturning GOP congressional map presents arguments against partisan redistricting ahead of pending nationwide ruling. A federal court in Cincinnati struck down Ohio's congressional map Friday, finding the state legislature's Republican majority drew an "unconstitutional partisan gerrymander" in 2012 that amplified GOP power far beyond the party's actual popularity.

title: White House Escalates Feud With Fed
summary: Most recent Trump administration request for more economic stimulus comes just after robust jobs report. WASHINGTON-Top White House and Federal Reserve officials squared off over interest rates Friday in a public clash over how to manage the economy at a time of strong growth and historically low unemployment.

title: Gordon McLeod Helped The Wall Street Journal and Other Publications Go Digital
summary: Vancouver-born executive held senior jobs at Newsday, Time and other firms during a 35-year career. Gordon McLeod, an executive who helped The Wall Street Journal and other publications improve their digital offerings, died April 26 at a hospital in New York. He was 60 years old and had been under treatment for cancer for nine years.

title: Sinclair to Buy 21 Regional Sports Networks From Disney
summary: TV-station giant values the deal at $10.6 billion. Sinclair Broadcast Group Inc. has reached a deal it valued at $10.6 billion to buy 21 regional sports networks from Walt Disney Co. , the companies said Friday.

title: U.S. Dollar Falls to End Week
summary: Strong April employment data also weighs on Treasury yields. The U.S. dollar declined Friday, weighed down by falling Treasury yields after fresh hiring data from the monthly jobs report.

title: Standing Against Psychiatry's Crazes
summary: In 1979 Dr. Paul McHugh closed the sex-change clinic at Johns Hopkins. In the '80s he testified against phony 'recovered memories.' He hasn't given up the fight.. Baltimore

title: Joe Biden Misses His Chance
summary: Along with every other Democrat, he surrendered his advantage when he lied about Donald Trump.. When he kicked off his presidential campaign last week, Joe Biden centered his rationale for running on a claim that Donald Trump referred to racists and neo-Nazis in Charlottesville as very fine people.

title: Blue-State Politics Are Eroding Little Rhody's Big Reforms
summary: Once hailed as a champion of fiscal sanity, Gov. Gina Raimondo has marched left since winning re-election.. Can a Democrat in a liberal state take on public-employee unions and survive? Rhode Island Gov. Gina Raimondo gave reformers reason to hope by handily winning re-election in November after a primary challenge from the left. As state treasurer, Ms. Raimondo pushed through the nation's boldest public pension reforms in 2011, which reduced political pressure to raise taxes. Rhode Islanders elected her governor in 2014. Early in her first term, she promoted a business-friendly environment. But that reform legacy and Rhode Island's future are now in question.

title: Secretariat's Kentucky Derby Record Is Safe, Thanks to the Taxman
summary: The 1986 reform act did away with incentives to use breeding as a shelter. Result: slower horses.. It's been 46 years since Secretariat ran the fastest race in the Kentucky Derby's 144-year history, at 1:59.4 minutes. Since then, only one other horse has completed the course in under two minutes-and he missed Secretariat's record by more than half a second. Odds are the record will survive this Saturday's race. Despite better training, technology and breeding for speed, racehorses haven't gotten faster since 1973.

title: Growth and the Working Class
summary: Wages are growing faster for the less skilled than for supervisors.. It's a good time not to be "privileged," to borrow the political vernacular of our progressive friends. Friday's labor report showed employers added 263,000 jobs in April as the unemployment rate dropped to 3.6%, the lowest in five decades. The best news is that the biggest beneficiaries of this tight labor market are the folks who struggled during the slow-growth Obama years.

title: The Pale Green New Deal
summary: Beto O'Rourke's climate agenda isn't much of one-but whose is?. As soon as the Vanity Fair photo crew left El Paso, the adulatory press for Beto O'Rourke's presidential campaign began fading. Hence his cry for attention this week in pitching a $5 trillion plan to stop global warming. "Muy buenos días from the Yosemite Valley," Mr. O'Rourke said in a web video, "where we are announcing the most ambitious climate plan in the history of the United States."

title: The Voter Suppression Myth
summary: Minority turnout surged in 2018, notably in Georgia and Florida.. Democrats accuse Republicans of suppressing the minority vote with laws to ensure ballot integrity. But then how do they explain record minority turnout last November? If Republicans were trying to stop minorities from voting, their schemes were inept.

title: Billionaire Tied to $6.5 Million Payment for Stanford Is Window Into China's Elite
summary: Pharmaceutical executive Zhao Tao led delegation of entrepreneurs to event in Washington and met with President Trump. BEIJING-The parents behind the largest-known payment in the college admissions scandal offer a window into the elite world of the ultrawealthy Chinese business class.

title: Cord-Cutting Clips Dish Network's Profit
summary: Company loses 266,000 satellite customers as dispute with HBO drags on; executives promise 'state-of-the-art' wireless network. Dish Network Corp.'s first-quarter profit fell 7.6% as its satellite-TV customer base continued to shrink, adding pressure on the telecom company to find new income sources.

title: U.S. Hiring Jumped in April; Unemployment Falls to 3.6%
summary: Stronger-than-expected April job gains point toward solid growth, though fewer Americans are working. WASHINGTON-The U.S. labor market showed historic strength in April, with employers hiring at a faster pace and the unemployment rate falling to a half-century low.

title: Marijuana Landlord's Bankruptcy Withstands Justice Department Appeal
summary: U.S. appeals court sides with Washington state landlord who collected rent from cannabis business. A federal appeals court has denied the Justice Department's request to unravel the debt-repayment plan of a Washington landlord who collected rent from a licensed marijuana-growing business.

title: Trump and Putin Discuss Venezuela, Mueller Report
summary: Mr. Trump said 'we didn't discuss that' when asked if he had sought assurances that Moscow wouldn't try to influence future U.S. elections. WASHINGTON-Donald Trump and Vladimir Putin discussed two thorny topics-Venezuela and North Korea-in a more than hourlong phone call Friday, but the U.S. president didn't press his Russian counterpart on another sensitive subject: Moscow's meddling in the American political system.

title: House Ethics Panel Reopens Probes of Three Republicans
summary: Committee reauthorized inquiries into Reps. Chris Collins of New York, Duncan Hunter of California and David Schweikert of Arizona. WASHINGTON-The House Ethics Committee is reopening investigations into three Republican lawmakers accused of campaign-finance and insider-trading crimes and other violations, the committee said Friday.

title: U.S. Stocks Rise on Strong Jobs Data
summary: Jobs report for April was above expectations; bond yields fall.. U.S. stocks rallied Friday, flipping the S&P 500 positive for the week and leaving it a hair below its record, after data showed the U.S. labor market added more jobs than expected in April.

title: Green River Project Debuts 50 One-Off Pieces at Object & Thing
summary: The design LLC has tables and seating scattered around the fair. Ben Bloomstein and Aaron Aujla founded Green River Project LLC in 2017 to make furniture in the fluid space between art and design. Their latest release, about 50 one-off pieces in materials ranging from African mahogany to fiberboard, debuts at Object & Thing, a new Brooklyn fair running May 3 to 5. The brainchild of Abby Bangser, a former Frieze Art Fair artistic director, Object & Thing is skipping booths in favor of a single installation overseen by Rafael de Cárdenas. Scattered around are the Green River Project tables and seating-for use and for sale (from $3,500). object-thing.com.

title: Florida Bill Requires Felons Pay Fines Before Voting Rights Restored
summary: GOP lawmakers say measure clarifies voter-approved amendment; opponents say measure narrows its scope. Florida lawmakers passed a divisive bill to implement a voter-approved constitutional amendment that restored voting rights to an estimated 1.4 million people with felony convictions.

title: In Reversal, NIH to Allow Doctors to Speak to Investigators
summary: Federal probe is looking into patient-safety issues in sepsis study. WASHINGTON-The leadership of the National Institutes of Health has reversed course and will allow two senior doctors to speak with federal investigators regarding patient-safety issues in a nationwide trial of treatment for the bloodstream infection sepsis.

title: Sri Lanka Bombers Secured Unusual Source of Help: Their Families
summary: Unlike many terrorist organizations, Islamic State draws wives and children into attacks. KALMUNAI, Sri Lanka-At dusk last Friday, armed troops and police closed in on a safe house linked to the plotters of the coordinated Easter Day suicide bombings. Gunfire erupted from inside. Three explosions rocked the home.

title: U.S. Government Bond Prices Climb as Wage Growth Disappoints
summary: Wage data increases concerns about slow inflation. U.S. government bond prices rose Friday after jobs data showing a slower-than-expected rise in wages exacerbated concerns about slow inflation.

title: 'The Last Days of the Mighty Mekong' Review: A River's Own Long Journey
summary: Filled with vivid descriptions of the places its author visits and the people he encounters, Brian Eyler's book reads like a travelogue but also a stark warning that the longest river in Southeast Asia is heading for irreparable ruin.. Some rivers are so still, so complacent, so dead that they leave the heart indifferent. Not the Mekong, the longest river in Southeast Asia. Fed by the melting snow and mountain streams of the Tibetan Himalayas, it tumbles down sheer-sided gorges in southwestern China, winds through the jungle hills of Laos, descends a series of rapids into Cambodia, then flows serenely into southern Vietnam before merging into the South China Sea near Ho Chi Minh City, formerly Saigon.

title: Mississippi River Cities Brace for More Damage as Floodwaters Move Toward St. Louis
summary: Communities fill sandbags, shut down businesses. Mississippi River cities rushed to sandbag and evacuate downtown homes and businesses as floodwaters that overwhelmed defenses in Davenport, Iowa, earlier in the week headed downstream toward St. Louis.

title: Young South Africans Chafe Under the Party Mandela Built
summary: Millions of young black voters born after the end of apartheid have known little but poverty and marginalization following years of ANC governance. ALEXANDRA, South Africa-A quarter-century after Nelson Mandela became this nation's first black president, his African National Congress is struggling to overcome skepticism from an unlikely part of the electorate: young black voters born into a democratic South Africa.

title: Wells Fargo Raises Estimate of Possible Losses From Legal Action
summary: In regulatory filing, bank sets upper range at $3.1 billion, up from $2.7 billion. Wells Fargo & Co. increased the amount of money it could lose from possible legal action, according to its quarterly securities filing.

title: Adidas Picks Up Pace in Race Against Nike in North America
summary: The sportswear maker expects to role out new products from its Beyoncé collaboration by the end of the year. BERLIN- Adidas AG said it was on track to resolve supply-chain issues holding back sales in North America by the end of the year, easing concerns that the sportswear maker could stumble in its sales race against rivals Nike Inc. and Under Armour Inc. in the world's most important athletic gear market.

title: Fiat Chrysler Sees 29% Drop in Operating Profit
summary: In key U.S. market, overall auto sales begin to slow after more than a half-decade of uninterrupted growth. Fiat Chrysler Automobiles NV's operating profit in the first quarter declined 29% as the auto maker posted lower sales globally, including in its key U.S. market.

title: Marriott CEO Diagnosed With Pancreatic Cancer
summary: Hotel executive says the cancer was discovered early; no leave of absence currently planned. Marriott International Inc., the world's biggest hotel operator, said Friday that its chief executive, Arne Sorenson, has been diagnosed with pancreatic cancer and will undergo chemotherapy.

title: Newell Brands Swings to a Loss, Sales Continue to Fall
summary: Maker of Rubbermaid containers and Elmer's glue continues search for its next CEO. Newell Brands Inc. swung to a loss and met sales expectations in its latest quarter as the consumer-products conglomerate continues its search for its next chief executive amid weak results.

title: Brexit-Fatigued English Voters Punish Main Parties in Local Elections
summary: The vote was the first major ballot since the postponement of Britain's scheduled departure from the bloc. LONDON-Britain's ruling Conservative Party and the main opposition Labour Party suffered setbacks in English local elections, suggesting widespread frustration over the two parties' handling of the U.K.'s withdrawal from the European Union.

title: Paul Winfree Under Consideration for Federal Reserve
summary: The former domestic policy aide in the Trump White House now oversees economic policy at The Heritage Foundation. WASHINGTON-President Trump's next nominee to the Federal Reserve board may be one of his former domestic policy aides who now oversees economic policy studies at the conservative Heritage Foundation.

title: Bitcoin's Rise May Be Bad for Bitfinex
summary: Rally in cryptocurrency to a 2019 high could be a reflection of the exchange. The price of bitcoin hit a 2019 high on Friday, but the gain may be less about demand for bitcoin and more about problems at the embattled exchange Bitfinex.

title: Investors Love Fake Meat. Will Consumers?
summary: An historic first day of trading for a manufacturer of plant-based products.. For roughly half a century a segment of the food industry has been trying to persuade consumers to give up beef. Will the movement finally succeed? History says no, but some investors seem to believe that this time is different.

title: Oil Notches Second-Straight Weekly Decline
summary: Concerns rise over surging U.S. oil inventories. • Oil rose slightly Friday after a strong U.S. jobs report, but fell weekly for a second consecutive week amid growing concerns over bulging domestic oil inventories.

title: Warehouse Hiring Surges on Rising E-Commerce Demand
summary: Logistics gains in April came as job growth for other transport operators lost steam. Warehouse operators stepped up hiring in April as e-commerce demand drove up employment in distribution centers even as job growth across the rest of the freight-transportation sector slowed.

title: Gold Rallies With Dollar, Treasury Yields Sliding After Jobs Report
summary: Prices are roughly flat for the year and almost 5% below their 10-month peaks hit in February. Gold prices climbed Friday, supported by a falling dollar and lower Treasury yields after April hiring data showed U.S. wages grew less quickly than expected.

title: SoftBank Considers IPO for $100 Billion Vision Fund
summary: Vision Fund staff hustles to keep up with frantic pace of deal making by CEO Masayoshi Son. SoftBank Group Corp. is considering audacious fundraising plans, including a public offering of its $100 billion investment fund and the launch of a second fund of at least that size, as it looks to seize on an exploding startup scene, people familiar with the matter said.

title: Only Markets Can Make the Green New Deal Real
summary: The activists are right about the urgency of averting climate change, but government fiat can't bring the price tag down to a politically tolerable level. The architects of the Green New Deal want to tackle climate change with a World War II-scale mobilization designed to replace fossil fuels with renewable energy in as little as a decade. And they think that the federal government, not markets, should determine how. On Monday, Democratic presidential candidate Beto O'Rourke unveiled a $5 trillion, 10-year plan to reduce greenhouse-gas emissions through government dictates such as stiffer fuel-efficiency standards.

title: Mester Says She Fully Supports Fed's Patient Stance
summary: Cleveland Fed leader says risks confronting economy are balanced, inflation weakness likely in part transitory. Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland President Loretta Mester said April jobs report was evidence of a strong employment sector and central-bank policy is in the right place for now.

title: 7 Past Décor Fads Worth Bringing Back
summary: Sunken living rooms? Tuscan-style kitchens? We asked 200 interior designers which trends they'd like to resurrect from the depths of the past-and which are better left forgotten. When it came to past fads they'd like to see exhumed, many of the 200 design pros we polled decisively said Art Deco. Some singled out 1970s sunken living rooms, though others put such pits at the bottom of the list. And not one of our experts supported a wobbly return for waterbeds. Here, what's due for a comeback and what's considered done.

title: Key Sector of Economy Is Slowing, But Economists Think It May Be a Good Thing
summary: Services-sector gauge fell for second straight month, but data shows moderate growth. WASHINGTON-Growth in the services industries-the main component of the U.S. economy-slowed for the second month in a row, but analysts think it could be a sign the economy is settling into a steady pace of growth.

title: The Charming Letters of One of America's Painting Legends
summary: Joan Mitchell's lively correspondences give the world a new vision of the American abstract expressionist. The American abstract expressionist painter Joan Mitchell rose to prominence during the second half of the 20th century; she was known for her large-scale canvas works, an outpouring of exuberant brushstrokes and blazing color. Mitchell was one of the rare women artists of her time to achieve the same level of acclaim as her male contemporaries, like Willem de Kooning and Jackson Pollock-as a result, the sort of myths often applied to male artists built up around her as well. She is remembered as temperamental, consumed by her art, or as a noble renegade, relentless in her pursuit of some undeniable greater truth.

title: How to Read the Label of a Sonoma Pinot
summary: Terroir-minded wine lovers look for the name of the place where it was produced. But what does that really tell you about a bottle?. The second in a three-part series on Sonoma, Calif.

title: A selection of Joan Mitchell's paintings on view at David Zwirner's West 20th Street gallery in New York
summary: Joan Mitchell: I carry my landscapes around with me is on view through June 22. Plus: some archival photos of the artist's life. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Inslee Unveils Climate Proposal in Line With Green New Deal
summary: Washington state governor's plan would have the U.S. on a path to all renewable and zero-emission energy in electrical power by 2035. WASHINGTON-Gov. Jay Inslee proposed Friday that the U.S. should require carbon-neutral power by 2030, laying out a climate plan at the start of his presidential campaign that embraces elements of the Green New Deal, which many Democrats have backed.

title: Probe of Former Apple Supplier of iPhone Glass Is Settled
summary: GT Advanced Technologies, which emerged from bankruptcy in 2016, settled the SEC probe and its former CEO agreed to pay $140,000. WASHINGTON-A former supplier to Apple Inc. agreed Friday to settle civil fraud claims that it misled investors about its problems making scratch-resistant sapphire glass for iPhones.

title: Syrian, Russian Strikes Renew Fears of Offensive to Recapture Stronghold
summary: Barrel bombs are dropped on villages bordering the front line separating the opposition and government forces. BEIRUT-Syria's government and Russia have intensified airstrikes and dropped barrel bombs on the last rebel stronghold in Syria, renewing fears of a military offensive to recapture the area despite the United Nations warning it would cause a humanitarian catastrophe.

title: New Hampshire Governor Vetoes Death-Penalty Repeal Bill
summary: Measure had enough support on prior votes for veto override. New Hampshire Gov. Chris Sununu vetoed a bill that would overturn the last law in New England allowing the death penalty, teeing up an expected override in the legislature.

title: If Trump Could Only Lose the Other Half . . .
summary: Destabilizing the entire town and showing the so-called experts (swamp dwellers) the door is exactly why we voted for him.. Peggy Noonan has it exactly right about how we common folks in flyover country feel about the Democrats continuing to harass President Trump ("How Trump Lost Half of Washington," Declarations, April 27). We would view it as a "cynical attempt by the left to achieve by other means what it couldn't achieve at the ballot box," and as "subverting democracy." She has it wrong that President Trump should have courted the "old ambassadors," as she calls them. Ms. Noonan states that by alienating these "experts" the president destabilized the entire town. Destabilizing the entire town and showing the so-called experts (swamp dwellers) the door is exactly why we voted for him. They are the ones responsible for all of the cultural decline we are experiencing in the U.S., as adeptly pointed out by Fergus M. Bordewich's op-ed, "Even George Washington May Be Erased From Our Past," right below Ms. Noonan's piece. If that happens, we have lost the U.S., and President Trump is the best option we've had in decades to turn this around.

title: Humanities Will Survive Progressive Assault
summary: The humanities are not dead but moribund because many professors who were once humanists have turned into ideologues.. The humanities are not dead but moribund because many professors who were once humanists have turned into ideologues, setting off culture wars that have pitted traditionalists against radicals who spew clichés like "diversity" and "inclusiveness" and who vitiate the canon by bringing in works of dubious literary merit to placate students clamoring for anything other than the dead, white European males, without whom Western culture wouldn't exist ("Stop Worrying About the 'Death' of the Humanities," Review, April 27).

title: Tesla Completes $2.35 Billion Stock and Bond Sale
summary: The capital raise provides a much-needed boost as the company pushes to become the first mass electric-car maker. Tesla Inc. has completed a $2.35 billion stock and bond sale, giving the company a much-needed boost of liquidity as it continues its quest to become the first mass producer of electric cars.

title: Fiat Chrysler Is Too American to Merge With Peugeot
summary: First-quarter results are a reminder that investors are mainly focused on FCA's profitable U.S. business. Fiat Chrysler Automobiles is one of the car industry's few examples of a successful trans-Atlantic merger, yet investors now view the company as all-American-and with good reason.

title: To Fix Capitalism, We May Need More Capitalism
summary: The private sector is creating solutions for social needs such as housing and child care. Every self-respecting capitalist, it seems, is rushing to the aid of capitalism. James Dimon, chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, and Ray Dalio, founder of Bridgewater Associates, the world's biggest hedge fund, both made headlines recently with eye-catching observations on the troubled condition of the U.S. economy. Mr. Dalio's mood is apocalyptic: "I believe that all good things taken to an extreme can be self-destructive and that everything must evolve or die," he wrote recently. "This is true for capitalism."

title: This App Helps You Hook Up With Random (Business) Partners
summary: A video-only networking app marries LinkedIn's scope for making professional connections with Tinder's ease of rejecting unappealing ones. Here's our critique. IF INFLUENCERS have taught us anything, it's the value of knowing your best angles. That's why video-based social-media apps particularly target millennial and Gen Z users, who favor YouTube, Instagram and Snapchat over Facebook or Twitter . And why Wonderloop, a networking app for sharing video profiles, might be those users' next go-to app.

title: HBO's Chernobyl Director on Recreating the Disaster's Agony
summary: It took 400 extras, rain shoots and directing "in the trenches:" how Breaking Bad veteran Johan Renck, music-video director to Bowie and Beyoncé, brought the harrowing nuclear accident back to life. Director Johan Renck believes art is best when its creation is difficult. "If I feel the labor and the gruesome process, that helps me appreciate the art," he says, lounging on a couch in the den of his Park Slope brownstone, where he lives with his wife of six years, Elin, and their four children. It's mid-April, and it's been just two weeks since Renck wrapped up post-production for the HBO limited series Chernobyl, a historical drama depicting the real-life events of the 1986 nuclear disaster. (It premieres May 6.) "Art is never finished," the tall, bearded and commanding Swedish director says, a touch tongue-in-cheek. "It is only abandoned."

title: Inside the home of Johan Renck
summary: The Chernobyl director takes WSJ. inside his eclectic Park Slope brownstone. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: GOP Traditionalists Thwart Trump's Push to Install Supporters at the Fed
summary: Senate opposition sinks Cain and Moore nominations, but other partisan picks may still loom. At first blush, the decision by a second Trump-selected candidate for the Federal Reserve Board to withdraw in as many weeks marks a win for the central bank's defenders, who had warned that former campaign adviser Stephen Moore and former Republican presidential candidate Herman Cain were too partisan for the technocratic Fed.

title: Fed's Bullard Says He Isn't Ready for Rate Cuts
summary: Central banker says shift in Fed policy guidance made financial conditions significantly easier, in a development akin to lowering rates. Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis President James Bullard said it isn't yet time to consider lowering interest rates, although one of his colleagues, Chicago Fed leader Charles Evans, said such a move may be in the works if inflation doesn't pick up.

title: T-Mobile Executives Leave Amid Management Reorganization
summary: Executive departures cover 5G, television, Metro prepaid units. Three senior executives are leaving T-Mobile US Inc. as the cellphone carrier consolidates some of its management structure, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: A Trove of Vivid Villains
summary: Robert Louis Stevenson's 'Treasure Island' revels in its captivating rogues' gallery of characters..

title: Five Best: Tunku Varadarajan on Tales of Lust
summary: The executive editor at Stanford University's Hoover Institution and adjunct professor at New York University recommends fiction unafraid of the risqué.. By Junichirō Tanizaki (1960)

title: 'Eric Hobsbawm: A Life in History' Review: The Outsider as Insider
summary: The popular Marxist historian had a vivid style, a superiority complex and the blind spots of a true believer.. Early in 1998, the historian Eric Hobsbawm went to Buckingham Palace to be made a Companion of Honour, thereby joining one of the most distinguished orders in British public life. As always with Queen Elizabeth II, few if any knew her thoughts, but the palace building made its own feelings clear enough. As the queen presented the order's official insignia, a piece of plaster fell from the ceiling, missing the historian and thereby narrowly avoiding what the British might understatedly term "an unfortunate incident."

title: 'Mind Fixers' Review: There Has to Be a Better Way
summary: In 57% of studies, a drug was no more efficacious than a placebo in easing depression.. The Whig interpretation of psychiatry's history begins with the great German clinician Emil Kraepelin struggling to grasp the complexity of psychosis by observing what his patients said and did over time. His systematic study of symptoms, signs and the course of illness enabled his discovery of dementia praecox and manic-depressive insanity-predecessor diagnoses to schizophrenia and bipolar disorder, respectively. In the decades straddling the dawn of the 20th century, Kraepelin and his contemporaries sought to uncover the biological basis of these diseases. Unfortunately, a Dark Age intervened after Sigmund Freud conquered the field. At last, after a 50-year detour through the psychoanalytic wilderness, psychiatry returned to its medical roots, led by the neo-Kraepelinians whose discoveries in psychopharmacology, genetics and neuroscience confirmed that mental disorders are brain diseases after all.

title: 'The Guarded Gate' Review: Bigotry and Bad Science
summary: Advocates claimed eugenics was a step toward scientifically grounded policy making.. In his insightful exploration of the "prehistory" of the Holocaust, "Why the Germans? Why the Jews?" (2011), the German historian Götz Aly observed that the Nazis' racial theories were significant not so much in fomenting anti-Semitism, which was already ingrained among all social strata of Germany and Austria by the time Hitler arrived on the scene, as in making that hatred acceptable to the haters. The idea that an objective, scientific theory of racial purity lay behind their antipathy to the Jews, Mr. Aly wrote, allowed Germans "to conceal their shameful, base resentment of others behind supposedly more sophisticated arguments."

title: 'Furious Hours' Review: A Story Still Untold
summary: There were rumors Harper Lee was scribbling away at a true-crime book. But few knew about the case of murder and vengeance that transﬁxed the author.. Friends of Harper Lee knew to heed certain unspoken rules. Most sensed that it was best not to ask her what she was working on. They also learned not to express concern over her excessive drinking, or to indulge the prying questions of yet another meddlesome biographer. Most of all, nearly everyone-from her closest relatives to her Upper East Side neighbors in New York-understood that they should never, ever, bring up "To Kill a Mockingbird." Lee's acclaimed 1960 novel may have brought her fame, fortune and millions of readers, but it had also become a millstone. In 1962, upon the release of the Oscar-winning film adaptation, Lee told a reporter in her native Alabama that she wanted to disappear. After giving one last interview two years later, she largely receded from view until her death in 2016, at the age of 89, in an assisted-living facility a few streets from where she grew up.

title: 'The Pioneers' Review: When Ohio Was the Frontier
summary: In late 1787, 48 settlers left New England. They then spent four months slogging 700 miles through the Alleghenies.. In the five decades since publishing his first book, "The Johnstown Flood," David McCullough has become perhaps our best-loved chronicler of America's past. He is also one of our most decorated, having earned two Pulitzer Prizes (for "John Adams" and "Truman") and two National Book Awards (for "The Path Between the Seas" and "Mornings on Horseback"), not to mention the Presidential Medal of Freedom. Over his long career, Mr. McCullough has taken on a few epic stories, such as the building of the Panama Canal. But more often he has chosen to shine a lantern into the underappreciated corners of American history, such as the 1889 flood in Johnstown, Pa., or, for that matter, the life of Harry Truman. His latest book, "The Pioneers," continues in this vein, chronicling the first permanent white settlement in the Northwest Territory. In the process, it sheds light on pioneers everywhere.

title: Fiction: The List of Varian Fry
summary: A novel about a Harvard man whosmuggled Jewish artists out of occupied France.. They also serve who sit at desks and shuffle papers. World War II was fought on all fronts, including the featureless realm of bureaucracy. Nazi Germany was infamous for the scrupulousness and drone-like efficiency of its apparatchiks. Their opposite numbers were the scattered divisions of Allied administrators-civil servants, diplomats, organization directors and all their unremembered underlings. Their work wasn't glamorous, but it was necessary. And some among them were heroes.

title: 'Now, Now, Louison' Review: Dance of the Spider Woman
summary: A memoir of Louise Bourgeois brings the sculptor down to earth without dispelling her unique glamour.. In more ways than one, the sculptor Louise Bourgeois lived a monumental life. There was, to begin with, her life itself: 98 years spanning most of the 20th century and some of the 21st, from the eve of the Great War to Barack Obama's first term. Then, the vastness of her productivity (hundreds of sculptures, prints, paintings and drawings), of her artworks (the largest weigh a few tons) and, more recently, of the literature about her (Robert Storr's 828-page appreciation "Intimate Geometries: The Art and Life of Louise Bourgeois," published in 2016, probably outweighs certain of her bronzes).

title: Mysteries: A Sheriff With Blood on His Hands
summary: Brian Panowich's novel reintroduces readers to Clayton Burroughs, a Georgia sheriff unfortunately born into the region's pre-eminent outlaw clan.. Readers first met Clayton Burroughs, a small-town Georgia sheriff, in Brian Panowich's acclaimed debut, "Bull Mountain" (2015). As encountered in that book's worthy sequel, "Like Lions" (Minotaur, 307 pages, $26.99), Burroughs is a diminished man: He's suffering from wounds acquired in the line of duty, guilt-ridden over having slain his own brother (also work-related) and dulling his senses and abilities with frequent doses of whiskey and oxycodone.

title: Coverdells vs. '529' Accounts: The Winner Is...
summary: Saving for College: We also answer a reader's question on whether you can have joint owners on a 529 account. Readers wrote in with questions about the smartest ways to use college-savings accounts like 529s. We asked experts to help us answer them.

title: 'The Power of Cute' Review: Danger: Totally Adorbs
summary: The irresistible allure of kittens, puppies, Pokémon and 'the face of a child drawn on a melon.'. Most Americans now have in their pockets a computer that can call up the greatest riches of human civilization at the tap of a forefinger, and we use them to look at cat videos. Is there something wrong with us? Simon May thinks so. "The Power of Cute" is a pint-size book with an ambitious aim: to explain the zeitgeist of the Instagram age.

title: The ABCs of Interest-Free College Loans
summary: These loans typically aren't designed to cover the entire cost of college, but for some students, they could be a good way to fill funding gaps. When it comes to paying for college, interest-free loans often fall under the radar. But for some students, they could be a viable alternative to costlier private student loans.

title: Children's Books: The Jobs That Mothers Do
summary: A new book celebrates the many professions a mother has to master: doctor, art curator, quartermaster, even impromptu dance-party disc jockey.. When my children were small, I used to joke that they worked in distribution and I worked in consolidation. What with the strewing of toys and books, I always enjoyed full employment. To be a mother is to have a great many professions, as Holman Wang points out in a celebration of maternal versatility, "Great Job, Mom!" (Tundra, 32 pages, $16.99).

title: OK Google, How's YouTube Doing?
summary: It's almost impossible to get financial specifics about the video-streaming service that helps power Alphabet's ad business. For investors, that's a problem.. Humans stream more than 1 billion hours of its videos per day, making it as ubiquitous in today's culture as VCRs, cassette decks and the Nightly News were when I was a kid.

title: Why Disney Took a Big Haircut on Sports
summary: The last act in Disney's deal drama looks as good for Sinclair as it is disappointing for Disney. The last act in Disney 's deal drama has been its search for a buyer of the 22 regional sports networks it acquired as part of its takeover of 21st Century Fox. The lucky winner is Sinclair Broadcast Group Inc., according to reporting from The Wall Street Journal. The deal looks as good for Sinclair as it is disappointing for Disney.

title: Renoir's Radical Beauty
summary: The French painter is known for idyllic nudes, but a new show reveals him as a risk-taking innovator. Pierre-Auguste Renoir (1841-1919) is often thought of today as a painter of smiling nudes in idyllic surroundings. But during his lifetime, he provoked a surprising amount of controversy. From his early impressionist works to his late experimental paintings featuring deliberately misshapen figures, Renoir's anti-academic style often made him a target of the critical establishment.

title: Inside the Revival of West Hollywood's Most Enduring Dive
summary: Elvis famously tipped a waitress here-with a Cadillac. The enduring legend of Formosa Cafe, now restored to its former glory. The Formosa Cafe, opened in 1939, is West Hollywood's most enduring dive. Known for its classic cocktails, greasy Cantonese cooking and kitschy black-and-red lacquered décor, it's had many lives in its 80 years. Elvis once tipped a waitress there with a Cadillac (or so the story goes). Frank Sinatra drank there in the 1950s, Warren Beatty in the '70s. In the '80s and '90s, you might have seen the Beastie Boys or Bono sipping a Mai Tai. Chef-owner Lem Quon presided over the dining room from 1948 until his death in 1993. Efforts to raze the building were long met with opposition. Then, in 2016, Quon's grandson Vince Jung shut the place down.

title: Think You Can't Afford a Mural? Not Necessarily
summary: New technologies have taken some of the risk, expense and rich-person stuffiness out of covering a wall with a single stunning image. TALK OF MURALS tends to conjure 18th and 19th century panoramas, hand painted to graphically retell, say, an African safari braved by the gentleman adventurer who commissioned the installation. Adding one to your own space might seem equally egoistic-and involved. But easily achievable new options that exploit robot assembly, large-scale printing and very forgiving adhesives are making believers of even modest commitment-phobes.

title: 'Dark Pools' Draw More Trading Amid Low Volatility

Investors have gobbled up meat companies this year on the expectation that an epidemic in China's pig population will force the country's consumers to devour tons of imported protein. The rally has been frenzied, but there are still tasty morsels left on the table.

title: Boeing Test Pilots Lacked Key Details of 737 MAX Flight-Control System
summary: A culture of close collaboration between test pilots, engineering staff deteriorated in later stages of aircraft's development. Boeing Co. limited the role of its own pilots in the final stages of developing the 737 MAX flight-control system implicated in two fatal crashes, departing from a longstanding practice of seeking their detailed input, people familiar with the matter said.

title: Inside the House Committees Investigating Trump
summary: A look at where congressional probes stand. Seven House committees are conducting probes into President Trump's finances, businesses, relationships with foreign nations, White House security clearances, and portions of the Mueller report on obstruction of justice and Russian interference in the 2016 presidential election.

title: French as It's Now Really Spoken
summary: An American in Paris discovers a language that's part English, part African, part Arabic-and fully French. I've lived in France long enough now to realize the French never really say oui like we think they say it. More often than not, they pronounce it wayh, and it's usually with an inhale, as if they're talking while taking a drag on a cigarette. Which is often the case.

title: Stakes Remain High as the Premier League's Most Chaotic Season Winds Down
summary: Manchester City and Liverpool are locked in a title race for the ages, while only five points separate the teams from third to sixth place. LONDON-The high priest of attacking soccer was in Burnley last weekend, clinging to a 1-0 lead, when his faith began to crack. He no longer trusted that his team could keep the ball, play beautifully, and cruise to the final whistle. The pressure was suffocating. Perhaps for the first time in his career, Manchester City manager Pep Guardiola prepared to suspend his principles.

title: Tesla Looks to Raise $2.3 Billion Through a Bond and Stock Sale
summary: Electric-car maker faces heightened concerns about its dwindling cash reserves after posting one of its worst quarterly losses in history. Tesla Inc. is looking to raise as much as $2.3 billion through a bond and stock sale after the electric-car maker reported a steep quarterly loss last week that heightened concerns about its dwindling reserves of cash.

title: Uber Faces Class-Action Suit in Australia
summary: More than 6,000 taxi drivers and license holders say Uber operated illegally, furthering legal challenges ahead of its IPO. title: DOJ Warns Against Broad Penalty for Qualcomm in FTC Case
summary: Lawyers argue that any sanction has to do as little harm as possible to public and private interests. title: Kim Jong Nam Murder Affair Closes With Release of Vietnamese Woman
summary: Huong pleaded guilty last month to a reduced charge. KUALA LUMPUR-A Vietnamese woman who stood trial for killing the half-brother of North Korean dictatorKim Jong Un was released in Malaysia and will return home later Friday, ending a high-profile murder mystery.

In a win for Twentieth Century Fox Television, a judge has overturned the $128.5 million in punitive damages that an arbitrator awarded to the stars and producers of the crime drama "Bones."

title: Chinese Mother Who Paid $6.5 Million for a Shot at Stanford Says She Was Misled
summary: New details on the biggest known payment in the college admissions cheating scandal; her lawyer says it was supposed to be a donation for scholarships. The Chinese mother who paid a now-disgraced college counselor $6.5 million for help securing her daughter a spot at Stanford University did so thinking she was making a donation for scholarships, academic staff and athletic programs at the university, according to a statement provided by her lawyer Thursday.

title: Trump Says Moore Decided to Withdraw From Fed Process
summary: Withdrawal comes after Republican senators raised concerns about Moore's comments on women, personal financial issues and views of the Fed. title: Insys Co-Founder, Former Employees Convicted of Opioid Conspiracy

Kapoor, of engaging in a racketeering conspiracy designed to boost profits from the company's prescription opioid drug.

title: First Suits Are Filed Over Seized Cuban Properties After U.S. Lifts a Waiver
summary: Claimants to port assets confiscated by Castro regime in 1960 sue Carnival over business there. Two U.S. citizens sued cruise operator Carnival Corp. on Thursday in the first application of a long-dormant law allowing Americans to pursue legal action against foreign entities doing business in Cuba on property confiscated by the Castro regime.

title: CBS Misses Revenue Estimates Despite Jolt From Super Bowl
summary: Revenue from its direct-to-consumer streaming services reaches a record level.
